awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Data-Driven Metrology and Inspection Technology for Semiconductor Wafer-Level Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports research advancing wafer-level semiconductor manufacturing and inspection technology, establishing the data and technical architecture needed to ensure sustainable solutions and scaling digital innovation across the wafer metrology and inspection processes. This research will generate new knowledge and principles used in the wafer/thin-film inspection, metrology, design and manufacturing needed in the electronics industry. Modeling methodologies are created for the inspection capability of various defect types at wafer scale. Semiconductor metrology and inspection tools are presently stand-alone machines operated independently and there is an increasing need for creating an automated and integrated metrology and inspection across semiconductor manufacturing processes. This project can accelerate the semiconductor industry’s digital transformation through hardware and software integration, connectivity, intelligence, visualization, and flexible automation. An integrated and intelligent framework for semiconductor wafer/thin-film metrology and inspection technologies is developed to monitor, diagnose and control the quality of wafer-level defects, by using super-resolution 3D imaging process, as well as thin-film material properties. This grant supports the semiconductor manufacturing workforce development, providing research and education opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students including underrepresented groups to gain knowledge and hands-on experience in semiconductor technology. 


The semiconductor process automation and digitalization based on strobo-spectroscopy and dexel-based deep learning algorithms provide for a wafer/thin-film inspection and metrology capability to detect the wafer-level or packaging-level anomalies. A strobo-spectroscopy capability combined with a spectral imaging technology allows for the synchronized spectroscopic analysis and high-speed imaging capturing of both the spectral response and spatial images as the probe scans the wafer surface. The combined spectral response and camera images are converted to 3D data representations to train dexel-based deep learning algorithms and predict wafer grade, defect type, and defect locations. The dexel-based approach to 3D wafer topography data through 3D correlation Neural Network (CNN) and Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) architectures is established to improve computational speed and prediction accuracy. By combining strobo-spectroscopy and deep learning algorithms, this research will fill a critical knowledge gap in automated inspection technology and in the fundamental identification of the wafer and thin-film abnormalities and variation in material properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Semiconductors power modern technology, from smartphones to medical devices, making their quality and reliability crucial. Our NSF-funded research has improved semiconductor manufacturing by developing advanced wafer inspection and metrology techniques. The project established a data-driven, integrated and intelligent framework for semiconductor wafer/thin-film metrology and inspection technologies enabling to monitor, diagnose and control the quality of wafer-level defects and thin-film material properties by deep learning-based automated review systems for semiconductor manufacturing, and educated the future scientists and engineers in semiconductor manufacturing, raising awareness for semiconductor manufacturing workforce development at the university level.

One of the main goals of this project was to create an intelligent, automated framework for wafer defect inspection and quality control. Traditional methods rely on manual inspection, which is slow and prone to errors. Our team developed a deep learning-based system that automatically detects and classifies defects, significantly improving efficiency and reducing costs. Using computer vision and machine learning, this system enhances manufacturing processes, ensuring higher-quality semiconductors with minimal human intervention.

Another major innovation was the development of a 3D wafer profile reconstruction method using Fabry-Pérot interferometry. This non-contact, high-precision technique enables the early detection of both surface and internal defects. By reconstructing detailed 3D wafer profiles and measuring thickness, we have provided manufacturers with more effective tools for ensuring quality control. Additionally, we optimized spectrum analysis techniques, increasing processing speeds by 24.7 times, allowing real-time wafer inspection.

Beyond defect detection, our research improved real-time thin-film growth and surface roughness monitoring. Thin films play a critical role in semiconductor devices, and ensuring their uniformity is essential. Traditional monitoring methods have limitations in accuracy and real-time assessment. Our newly developed optical sensing technique provides instant feedback on thin-film thickness and surface roughness, enabling real-time quality control during manufacturing. This advancement helps manufacturers reduce waste and improve production reliability.

In addition to semiconductor applications, our research has impacted broader manufacturing fields, including micro/nano-manufacturing, electrochemical machining, and precision engineering. Our optical metrology techniques have been applied to machine straightness error monitoring and tool wear assessment, demonstrating their adaptability across various high-precision industries. These findings highlight the far-reaching impact of our project beyond semiconductor manufacturing.

A critical part of this project was training the next generation of semiconductor scientists and engineers. Throughout the grant period, we provided hands-on research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, equipping them with expertise in machine learning, optical metrology, and semiconductor inspection. Students worked on experimental testbeds, developed machine learning models, and contributed to real-world manufacturing solutions. Their involvement in academic publications and conferences further prepared them for careers in semiconductor research and industry.

Our research has led to multiple high-impact journal publications and collaborations with semiconductor companies to ensure practical application of our findings. By sharing our innovations through technical presentations and industry partnerships, we have contributed to improving best practices in wafer inspection and quality control. These collaborations strengthen the bridge between academic research and industrial implementation, ensuring our advancements benefit real-world semiconductor manufacturing.

Looking ahead, the technologies developed in this project will continue to shape the semiconductor industry. AI-driven defect detection and automated wafer inspection will become more precise and scalable. Real-time thin-film monitoring and 3D wafer profiling will further enhance production efficiency. As semiconductor devices grow smaller and more complex, the need for advanced inspection and metrology tools will increase. Our research provides a foundation for future breakthroughs in nanotechnology, microelectronics, and AI-driven manufacturing.

In conclusion, this project has transformed semiconductor manufacturing by improving defect detection, enhancing metrology, and fostering workforce development. By integrating cutting-edge machine learning and optical sensing techniques, we have provided practical solutions that increase efficiency, reduce costs, and improve the quality of semiconductor devices. The broader applications of our findings extend into precision manufacturing, engineering, and beyond, highlighting the versatility of our work.

This research was made possible through the support of the National Science Foundation (NSF), our dedicated research team, and industry collaborations. By bridging scientific discovery with industrial applications, we are paving the way for a more automated, efficient, and high-quality semiconductor manufacturing process, ensuring a reliable supply of advanced electronic technologies worldwide.
